Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Motion Control of Bacteria-Powered Microrobots

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to understand the control of bacterial propulsion systems, and to demonstrate the enabling technologies necessary for the feedback control of bacteria-actuated microstructures. Bacteria are ideal systems for many microbiorobotic systems, because of the ease of their ?gproduction and refueling?h. For this purpose, microbiorobots (MBRs) are constructed, which consist of flagellated bacteria integrated with fabricated microstructures. The bacterial cells propel the microstructures in fluidic environments. In this project, some design aspects for the MBRs are explored, including the effects of bacterial density, distribution and orientation on the surface of the MBRs, as well as various modalities to control the bacteria. A number of stimuli, including ultraviolet light, electromagnetic field, chemicals, and thermal stimuli are used as control inputs to the MBRs, while measurement feedback is provided by a computer vision-based system. Deliverables include mathematical models of the system behavior, experimental results on the bacteria morphology, microscopy visualization, prototypical demonstration of motion control, documentation of research results, engineering student education, and engineering research experiences for high school students and teachers.

If successful, the outcome of this research will represent a critical step toward understanding how to control bacterial propulsion systems to manipulate larger engineered elements, for example in microassembly and micromanipulation scenarios. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students will benefit from this project through classroom instruction and involvement in the research. The program will also be integrated with various outreach activities, including (i) microbiorobotics workshops at Drexel and RPI, (ii) active recruitment and training of women and under?]represented minority engineers by leveraging and expanding existing and proven programs already in place at Drexel and RPI, (iii) outreach to high school students and teachers at RPI, and (iv) interactive web?]based tutorials and exhibits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to develop control methods for microbiorobots. Microbiorobots are microscale robots that are inspired from biology, and we engineer microrobots from both synthetic and biological components, or use designs inspired from nature. These robots are smaller than the diameter of a human hair, and they will navigate fluid environments that are characterized by a low Reynolds number. As a result, they require special swimming mechanics different from swimming in a life sized pool. We use biologically inspired designs since organisms have already developed swimming mechanics to navigate these viscous force dominated environments. As an added advantage, organisms already have sensory organelles, and as a result, they can be controlled using a variety of stimuli, such as light, chemical gradients, magnetic fields, and electric fields; many of these behavioral responses are innate to the organism. To create a synthetic robot with a built in power system, swimming mechanism, and sensing devices while maintaining a platform size of less than 100 microns would be very difficult. We focus on three types of microbiorobots: (1) Bacteria powered microrobots (BPMs) are composed of a synthetic microstructure with bacteria blotted on one surface. These BPMs can be steered and actuated using electric fields. (2) Artificially magnetotactic Tetrahymena pyriformis (AMT) are protozoa that can swim up to 20 times their body length in speed. By introducing them to a solution of iron oxide, they can be magnetized and controlled using magnetic fields. They also respond to light, electric fields, and chemical gradients. (3) Achiral microswimmers are made of magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs). These MNPs are spherical in shape and can form various microswimmers composed of n amount of MNPs. By varying the frequency and strength of a rotating magnetic field, these swimmers can be steered and controlled.

Through this program, we have developed and achieved the necessary understanding and technical infrastructure:

  1. We have developed an obstacle avoidance navigation system for BPMs that enable them to navigate complex environments with electric fields, as these fields tend to become distorted around insulating objects.
  2. We have characterized the flow field of BPMs to understand their swimming mechanics near surfaces.
  3. We have developed mathematical models for AMT that demonstrate they can be controlled as a swarm using a single global input and validated the model with experimental data
  4. We have characterized the swimming behavior of Tetrahymena pyriformis under electric fields.
  5. We developed the achiral microswimmers by conjugating three magnetic bead using avidin biotin chemistry. Using a rotating magnetic field, we achieved velocity and direction control. In addition, we’ve demonstrated a multiple robot control strategy to simultaneously control more than one swimmer

The funding results in the publication of 4 conference papers, 4 journal papers, and XXX book chapter(s). X high school and Y undergraduate students participated in research experiences.
